        La pen?ltima


    La ?poca de los ladrones cultos

------------------------------------------------------------------------
*Enrique Naveda *
El 21 de agosto de 1911 Vincenzo Peruggia, un trabajador del Museo del 
Louvre, ocult? la Gioconda bajo su abrigo y atraves? satisfecho las 
puertas del edificio. En esos instantes, que lo convert?an en un 
personaje legendario, tal vez pensaba en el agradecimiento que le deb?a 
al marqu?s de Valfierno, inductor y cerebro del plan, sin saber que este 
lo traicionar?a. La Mona Lisa apareci? dos a?os despu?s, pero el robo se 
convirti? en uno de los m?s memorables de la historia del arte.

A nivel mundial, el oficio de ladr?n de arte se ha vuelto la tercera 
actividad ilegal m?s lucrativa. Se calcula que el mercado negro maneja 
alrededor de US$5 millardos al a?o. Seg?n un estudio realizado por 
Interpol en 2000, solo el narcotr?fico y el trasiego ilegal de armas lo 
superan.

M?xico, con 200 sustracciones anuales, seg?n su Instituto Nacional de 
Antropolog?a e Historia, es uno de los pa?ses que m?s lo padecen.

En lo que va del a?o, en Guatemala el Ministerio de Cultura y Deportes 
ha conocido el robo de im?genes religiosas de la ?poca colonial, y en el 
?ltimo lustro la cifra asciende a 254 piezas sustra?das.

Sin embargo, la estad?stica no es completa, reconoce ?scar Mora, jefe de 
la Unidad de Prevenci?n y Control del Tr?fico Il?cito de Bienes 
Culturales de esa dependencia. Las fuentes de informaci?n y denuncia del 
ente son precarias.

El mercado de bienes culturales guatemaltecos es variado, y en general 
las piezas se reparten por Estados Unidos y Europa. Las posibilidades de 
recuperar una pieza dependen mucho de su movimiento en el mercado negro, 
explica Mora, y a?ade que hay obras que se recuperan en cinco d?as y 
otras en cinco a?os.

Pero tambi?n hay unas terceras que no se recuperan nunca: los 
coleccionistas, sean nacionales o extranjeros, mantienen la obra oculta, 
en su cat?logo privado y fuera del conocimiento p?blico.

Cuando eso ocurre es complicad?simo localizarlas. Aunque gran parte de 
los intermediarios que se dedican a vender arte robado conocen a los 
coleccionistas y eso facilita la transacci?n, muchas veces se ubican las 
obras en el momento en que se trata de venderlas o van a cambiar de manos.

A escala internacional la Interpol es la responsable de coordinar la 
b?squeda. En los ?ltimos a?os se han reforzado las aduanas, se emplean 
localizadores satelitales y se cre? un registro de obras de arte 
desaparecidas, el Art Loss Register, el cual sirve a museos, casas de 
subastas, polic?a y coleccionistas para averiguar si la obra que se les 
trata de vender es robada.

En Guatemala, cuatro personas est?n condenadas y una m?s espera 
sentencia. El C?digo Penal establece prisi?n de 6 a 15 a?os.

Los coleccionistas, a menudo gente acaudalada con un nivel cultural 
alto, justifican muchas veces sus compras con el argumento de que ellos 
las conservar?n mejor que un museo. Y seguramente es cierto, admite 
Mora, se trata de bienes p?blicos que ellos vuelven privados, y por otra 
parte, robar arte o vestigios arqueol?gicos es sustraerle una pieza al 
rompecabezas de la memoria colectiva de un pa?s.

Recientemente, un coleccionista reconoci? ante el Ministerio de Cultura 
haber pagado Q25mil por un bien arqueol?gico. ?Estoy seguro de que esa 
pieza en el mercado internacional habr?a alcanzado valores mucho m?s 
altos?, asegur? Mora.

Guatemala, domingo 15 de abril de 2007

Investigan el robo de piezas de arte religioso en una iglesia de Honduras
Las autoridades de Honduras investigan el robo de al menos media docena 
de objetos de arte religioso ocurrido el fin de semana pasado en un 
templo cat?lico del oeste del pa?s, informaron hoy fuentes judiciales.

El hecho se registr? en la comunidad de Macholoa, departamento de Santa 
B?rbara, unos 340 kil?metros al noroeste de Tegucigalpa, dijeron fuentes 
del Ministerio P?blico, cuya Fiscal?a de Etnias y Patrimonio Cultural ha 
abierto la investigaci?n.

Los saqueadores se llevaron la corona de plata, dos aretes y dos cadenas 
de oro de la virgen de Santa Luc?a, la patrona de Macholoa, as? como un 
crucifijo tambi?n de oro.

Las fuentes dijeron a Acan-Efe que no se ha confirmado si tambi?n fue 
robada una biblia que, seg?n versiones de prensa, data de 1537.

El robo ocurri? en la noche del s?bado y fue descubierto el domingo en 
la ma?ana.

Pobladores de Machaloa dijeron a la prensa que el viernes lleg? a la 
comunidad un hombre desconocido a bordo de un autom?vil y pregunt? d?nde 
quedaba la iglesia, y el s?bado aparecieron otros dos extra?os, quienes 
tomaron fotos del templo.

Seg?n la prensa local, este es el tercer saqueo de objetos que se 
registra en el mismo templo; en las dos ocasiones anteriores, los 
ladrones se llevaron cuatro im?genes de santos y v?rgenes.

Las autoridades hondure?as no han podido contener los robos de piezas de 
arte religioso que frecuentemente se producen en el pa?s.

Sin embargo, en enero pasado la Fiscal?a y la Polic?a decomisaron, en 
distintas operaciones ejecutadas en Tegucigalpa, 17 piezas religiosas 
supuestamente robadas de varios templos.

    Roban biblia del siglo XVI de santuario en Honduras
martes, 17 de abril del 2007 11:22
Una biblia que est? escrita en lat?n y fue trasladada de Espa?a a 
Honduras en 1537 fue robada de un templo cat?lico en el oeste del pa?s 
centroamericano, dijeron la polic?a y responsables del recinto religioso.
El asalto habr?a sido cometido por dos hombres la madrugada del domingo 
en Macholoa, unos 200 kil?metros al oeste de Tegucigalpa.

"Los sujetos llegaron el s?bado al pueblo y me pidieron que les mostrara 
la biblia... y lo hice", dijo en rueda de prensa la encargada del templo 
Amparo Reyes. "Y la Biblia ya no estaba al d?a siguiente en la urna de 
vidrio que la proteg?a", agreg?.

Seg?n Reyes, los individuos forzaron con una barra de metal la puerta 
trasera del templo, se introdujeron al lugar, sustrajeron varios 
art?culos incluidos varios objetos de arte sacro y huyeron. Robaron 
adem?s una corona de plata de la patrona cat?lica Santa Luc?a, sus 
aretes y un crucifijo de oro, as? como amplificadores de sonido y un 
juego de cortinas regaladas que estaban en una maleta.

La polic?a dijo en un comunicado que investiga de manera intensa la 
situaci?n y se?al? que las reliquias sustra?das son vendidas a 
coleccionistas extranjeros.

Es la tercera vez en dos a?os que la iglesia de Macholoa es saqueada. 
Los sacerdotes del templo viven en comunidades cercanas y en el pueblo 
no hay polic?as.

El templo de Macholoa fue construido en 1537 por los conquistadores 
espa?oles. Desde el 2005 han sido saqueados al menos 30 templos 
cat?licos en seis provincias de Honduras: Santa B?rbara, Ocotepeque y 
Lempira, al oeste; Francisco Moraz?n y Comayagua, en el centro, y El 
Para?so, al este del pa?s.

Government-backed company claims all Nazi loot from museums

If heirs cannot be found, the intention is to sell the works with 
proceeds going to Holocaust survivors

By Lauren Gelfond Feldinger | Posted 18 April 2007
JERUSALEM. An Israeli Holocaust restitutions com?pany is asking museums 
in Israel to hand over all unclaimed Nazi-looted art and objects held in 
their collections, starting with the Israel Museum in Jerusalem.

Since 1951, Israeli museums have held unclaimed works of art seized from 
European Jews by the Nazis.

But survivors of the Holocaust and heirs of Nazi victims still do not 
know the full extent of works held in Israeli institutions, says Avraham 
Roet, the director of the Company to Locate and Return Assets to 
Holocaust Survivors. ?It?s been 60 years; survivors are dying daily, how 
much longer can they fight [for the recovery of their property]?? asks 
Mr Roet, himself a Holocaust survivor.

Since the assets recovery company was launched in November, it has 
focused on recovering land and money held by Israeli institutions but is 
now also focusing on the restitution of art and objects.

Mr Roet says that once he is in possession of works handed over by 
Israeli museums, his company is legally entitled to sell these to raise 
money for Holocaust survivors, if original owners or heirs cannot be 
found. Financed by government loans, the assets recovery company is 
expected to repay the loans in full using up to two percent of recovered 
assets, though it opposed this arrangement.

Israel Museum officials in Jerusalem say they were surprised to receive 
a letter from the assets recovery company a few weeks ago, demanding 
every unclaimed Holocaust-era object and work of art. ?We are now 
studying the legislation,? says museum director James Snyder. He argues 
that no organisation can preserve, exhibit and publish works of art 
better than a museum.

Since its founding in 1965, the Israel Museum has held some 550 
paintings, drawings and prints, and several hundred Judaica objects 
looted by the Nazis from European Jews. These were shipped to Israel in 
the early 1950s by the Jewish Restitutions Successor Organizations 
(JRSO), an umbrella organisation consisting of American, European and 
mandatory-Palestine Jewish associations. The JRSO was named custodian of 
unclaimed Nazi-looted properties at the 1946 Paris Reparations Conference.

Two hundred of the JRSO paintings and drawings at the Israel Museum were 
originally in the collection of the Berlin Jewish Museum, destroyed 
during the war, though the Israel Museum has placed many of these on 
long-term loan to the new Jewish museum in Berlin, designed by Daniel 
Libeskind.

Of the Israel Museum?s additional 350 Nazi-looted works of art with no 
ownership records, the most important and best preserved paintings are 
either on display or on loan, including Egon Schiele?s Krumau-Crescent 
of Houses, 1915, and Marc Chagall?s Praying Jew, 1914. Fifty of the JRSO 
Judaica items are currently on display. According to the museum, most 
works that are currently in storage arrived in poor condition and are of 
little art historical value.

?It?s important for us to continue to hold these works. Museums are 
appropriate venues for such custodianships, and in this case we were 
charged to be custodians,? says Mr Snyder. ?JRSO made a point of 
distributing cultural property with no prior ownership records to be 
held for the public good. The Egon Schiele, for example, belongs in a 
museum setting?especially in Israel?where it can be appreciated by the 
public.?

According to the Israel Museum, the arrival of the JRSO works in Israel 
was publicised at the time and resulted in the restitution of some 
works. To date, the museum has returned some 20 JRSO works to heirs of 
Nazi victims.

The museum has also returned two works it had not received from JRSO: an 
1897 Pissarro painting and an 1898 Degas drawing.

Because of an Israeli law enacted in January 2006 to create the assets 
company, Mr Roet believes that the JRSO mandate has now been superseded 
and the Israel Museum must list and display all works which could be 
claimed by Holocaust survivors or their heirs regardless of the works? 
value or condition before handing them over.

Last month officials from the company and the Israel Museum met for the 
first time. The museum is continuing to catalogue its JRSO material, 
anticipating publication, and will share this information with the 
company, which will also make it public, says Mr Snyder.

A company official says that an inventory of the works in the Israel 
Museum would only be ?a first step?.

Reward Offered For Family Heirlooms Stolen From Nova Scotia Residence

Mills Village, Queens Co., Nova Scotia, Canada:Up to $1,000 is being 
offered by the owners for information resulting in the arrest and 
conviction of individuals involved in the break-in of a residence here 
and the recovery of the substantial number of family antiques removed 
from the premises.

The break-in occurred some time between December 25 and March 1. The 
crime is being investigated by the RCMP Queens Detachment.

Reported missing are: an oil painting of Joseph Currier in gold leaf 
frame; an oil painting of Katherine Currier Jones; a tiptop black table 
with mother-of-pearl inlay; brass student oil lamp missing yellow shade; 
red glass vase; small black and white cow pitchers; large and small 
porcelain soup tureens of cows with flower garlands; large picture of 
Asenath Campbell under glass gold leaf frame 1870 photo portrait; family 
embroidered sampler by Asenath Mack Campbell; small ceramic figurine of 
lady; Chinese turquoise porcelain horse; brass lamp with two yellow 
shades originally oil converted to electric operation; and an Eskimo 
carving gray soapstone.

Also reported missing is Inuit carving seal hunter; various porcelain 
items; two red vases; mug; fishing boy figurine; birch bark moose call; 
Victorian ball and claw spindle top stool; Old Ironsides print framed 
behind glass; framed old sampler: "God is Love"; several hooked rugs; 
Cheticamp needlepoint rug; needlepoint view from Shelburne House by Lila 
Webb; framed envelope to C.H. Jones from Admiral Byrd; Masons member 
certificate for John Campbell; mahogany framed mirror; medium sized 
mahogany writing chest; brass candleholder; lithograph print; 
commemorative long leather strap with brass medallions (George VI, 
Edward VIII); and a pewter tea service.

Anyone who has seen any of these items, please contact the RCMP Queens 
Detachment at 902-354-5721. File number is 2007-220959.

http://antiquesandthearts.com/

MyThings Launches Online Registry of Belongings in the US at MyThings.com

2007-04-17 21:09:14 -

MENLO PARK, Calif., April 17 /PRNewswire/ -- MyThings, the global online 
registry of belongings, today announced it has formally launched its 
consumer website in the United States at MyThings.com. Introduced 
initially in the UK in December 2006, MyThings is the only web service 
to provide a true one-stop shop for managing and protecting valuable 
belongings.

"Say goodbye to your shoebox filled with receipts, warranties, and 
manuals -- and say hello to a secure and free web service from 
MyThings," says MyThings CEO, Benny Arbel. "We are thrilled to roll out 
the MyThings service in the US. By collecting all their important 
ownership information in one place, consumers get the control and peace 
of mind to enjoy the things they love most."

By creating a MyThings Portfolio on MyThings.com, consumers will be able 
to track the vital statistics of their belongings, as well as tap 
additional member benefits ranging from finding accessories and 
accessing product information, to downloads, warranties, insurance, and 
free valuations. These benefits help consumers manage and protect their 
valuables so they can get the most out of what they own.

On MyThings, consumers will find: -- Community generated content
Through MyThings Valuation, a unique appraisal service, members can 
submit their fine arts, antiques, and collectibles to designated 
specialists for free appraisal online-in effect, it's "Antiques 
Roadshow(R) meets Web 2.0". MyThings Valuation combines the informative, 
entertaining format of the television series with the power of community 
on the web. In addition, users can exchange useful information about 
their things through comments, messaging, forums, and stories.

-- Third party content
MyThings also brings a wide range of content and services to its members 
and visitors through partnerships that support shopping, product 
information, and market value data. For example, Terapeak provides the 
price of all items sold on eBay for the past 30 days; CNET Channel 
provides product descriptions and images for consumer electronics; and 
Become.com lists compatible accessories with online shopping and pricing 
information.

-- MyThings inventory
The MyThings Portfolio is the easiest and fastest way for a consumer to 
build and track an inventory of their valuable belongings. At the online 
point of sale, MyThings automatically enters product and purchase 
details into the member's portfolio. For items added directly by the 
consumer, MyThings assists with content from product databases. Ongoing 
engagement is based on items within the portfolio, where consumers share 
comments and MyThings partners offer relevant services and deals.

Since December 2006, MyThings has been demonstrating consumer acceptance 
by pre-populating portfolios at the point of sale with major online 
retailers and OEMs in the UK, such as Tesco Direct, Casio, Halfords, 
Jessops, and Goldsmiths. MyThings' API for partners allows direct 
insertion of important purchase details like the item name, description, 
image, brand, model, serial number, purchase location, date, and price. 
Not only do consumers benefit from having this information at hand 
whenever it's needed, MyThings' partners also benefit from highly 
targeted installed base marketing programs that drive customer loyalty 
and marketing ROI.

Today's launch also kicks off the MyThings Show & Tell contest. The 
contest showcases MyThings Valuation by selecting the most fascinating 
story of an item submitted for valuation each week and featuring it on 
the MyThings homepage. The best of the weekly winners will win the grand 
prize: a trip to London or New York City for two, accommodations at the 
Four Seasons Hotel, and a visit to a live auction at Christie's, 
Sotheby's, Bonhams, or Phillip with one of the MyThings Valuers. The 
Valuation feature and contest are available to users worldwide.

"Consumers are telling us that there is immediate value in populating 
portfolios automatically at the point of sale, as proven by the high 
conversion rates for new members who join us from our retail and OEM 
partners," continues Arbel. "The utility of capturing a digital receipt 
online is well-matched by the engaging elements of MyThings Valution, 
Market Value Estimator, and of course, the Show & Tell contest. Who 
doesn't have something hidden away in their attic or in plain sight with 
a story to tell?"

About MyThings Inc.
MyThings Inc. offers MyThings (MyThings.com) and Trace (Trace.com), two 
unique services designed to help people manage and protect their 
belongings, giving them control and peace of mind. MyThings is a 
consumer web service that provides secure online portfolios for managing 
belongings, as well as relevant information and services, including 
valuations, accessories, insurance, and warranties. MyThings serves as a 
trusted intermediary between buyers and sellers, delivering desired 
information without compromising the privacy of consumers or subjecting 
them to intrusive messages.

Trace is MyThings' online database of lost and stolen valuables. It is 
also the most diverse global registry of lost and stolen items, ranging 
from art and antiques, to jewelry, watches, and consumer electronics. 
Trace integrates information from over 50 sources, including local, 
national, and international law enforcement, plus members of MyThings.

Founded in 2004, MyThings has offices in Menlo Park, California; London, 
England; and Tel Aviv, Israel.

NOTE: MyThings is a trademark and Trace a registered trademark of 
MyThings, Inc. Antiques Roadshow, Terapeak, CNET Channel, Become.com, 
Tesco Direct, Casio, Halfords, Jessops and Goldsmiths are registered 
trademarks of their respective companies.
